Settings

The logic behind the Future Value of Annuity Formula is that you make equal deposits every year for a certain number of years, starting one year from now. The formula will then calculate, based on a given interest rate, how much these deposits will have accumulated to by the end of the years entered. A real world example for this would be equal deposits into a savings account for your retirement.
The number of years is:
Error on switch break
Valor Presente / Valor Futuro
Number of Periods per year: For interst that compounds (is applied) multiple times a year, it specifies how often in one year an annual interest rate is applied

Coupon Payments: The coupon payment is the money that you receive each year that you are holding the bond. Sometimes you will receive coupon payments multiple times a year; this refers then to the number of periods
Future Value: The future value of the Present Value, grown with cumulative interest for the number of years specified
Bonds: The present Value that a bond is worth today, taking into account both the discounted face value payment and the discounted annuity of the coupon payments.
Future Value of Annuity Due
Present Value of Bonds - Help Section

This formula calculates what the present value of a company’s bond is. A bond pays a certain number of coupon payments every year and returns the face value of the bond at its maturity (when it has run out). With this formula you can calculate how much based a bond is worth to you today, based on the return of its face value in the future as well as a series of discounted coupon payments.
Div-n: The dividends that were paid out "t" years ago.
The following equation is used:
The Interest Rate is:
Present Value: The present value sum of all annual payments discounted for the number of years specified

Present Value of Bonds
Future Value of Annuity - Help Section
Present Value: The value of a one-time cash flow today

The logic behind the Future Value of Annuity Formula Due is that you make equal deposits every year for a certain number of years, starting TODAY. The formula will then calculate, based on a given interest rate, how much these deposits will have accumulated to by the end of the years entered. A real world example for this would be equal deposits into a savings account for your retirement.
Choose from the slider below how many cash flows you want to discount
The Present Value is: $

La lógica detrás de esta fórmula es que a día de hoy el dólar no vale un dólar mañana . Por ejemplo , si usted deja $ 1000 en el banco por un año , que tendrá un valor de más ( Valor Futuro ) . Del mismo modo, cuando usted recibirá $ 1000 por año a partir de ahora , vale la pena a menos que usted ahora ( valor actual ).
Future Value of Annuity Due - Help Section
MyCalcFinance
Valor Presente / Valor Futuro - Sección de ayuda
Valor Presente de la Anualidad - Sección de ayuda

Si usted recibe pagos por un número de años , cada pago sucesivo vale menos porque usted tiene que esperar para ello. Cinco pagos de $ 5,000 por ejemplo, no son dignos de $ 25,000 pero si por menos (dependiendo del tipo de interés aplicado ). Esto calcula el valor que deben pagarle.
The Future Value of Annual Cash Flows is: $

Cash Flow: The annual cash flow received / made each year for the number of years specified

Hello world!
Growth Rate Calculation - Help Section
This formula calculates at what rate dividends (or any forms of cash flows) grew over a number of years.
Div0: The dividens that were paid out this year.
Interest Rate: The interest / discount rate applied to see how much the Present Value decreases / the Future Value increases by
Sorry! This feature will be coming soon!

The logic behind this formula is that if you receive payments for a number of years, each successive payment is worth less to you because you have to wait for it. Five payments of $5000 for example are not worth $25,000 but less (depending on interest rate applied). This formula calculates how much less the stream of payments is worth. However, for the Annuity Due, it is assumed that the first payment is made / received today. This means that it is essentially the cash flow today + the present value of the annuity for n-1 years.
Net Present Value Calculation - Help Section
